dataset.title: Territorial Empathy Maps Racial Inequality to Take Action
dataset.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Current and historical factors marginalize communities of color; maps make impacts clear.
  • GIS analysis pinpoints outcomes linked to inequities in education, financial security, and health care.
  • Breaking down dehumanization problems, an architect presents data visualization that drives empathy.

dataset.title: Segregation is Killing Us...
dataset.description:
In New York City, the destructive path of COVID-19 mirrors the destruction left by generations of segregated communities and schools. However, segregation is about more than the separation of people from each other. It is about separating historically marginalized people from resources, power, opportunity, and self-determination. It is about the proliferation of racial and economic stratification. It is about strategic over-policing, mass incarceration, and the murder of Black, Latinx, and Indigenous people with unchallenged impunity.

Segregation facilitates and upholds the concentration of privilege and vulnerability in our schools and communities.

Segregation facilitates and upholds the concentration of privilege and vulnerability in our schools and communities.
As Rucker Johnson points out in his book, Children of the Dream, segregation negatively impacts Black and Latinx communities’ access to healthcare, and their interactions with the carceral state. So we say again... Segregation is killing us.

dataset.title: Podcast: Accelerate Social Justice Using Technology
dataset.description: Darlene Flynn, community activist and Director of the Department of Race and Equity in Oakland, California, explains how governments and businesses are tackling racial inequity across their organizations. Esri’s David Gadsden investigates how mapping and sophisticated analysis can help identify systemic racism and promote equity.

dataset.title: People and Places, Not Points and Lines
dataset.description: When geographers and planners of color hold the opportunity to frame and use the powerful, exploratory tools of geoscience, outstanding work is possible—work that creates a path for responsible and effective decision-making in matters of community planning, public health, economic development, business creation, housing and homeownership, and much more. Once we commit ourselves to a more diverse and representative geospatial practice, we will be committing to a future of thriving, healthy, equitable neighborhoods, towns, and cities.

dataset.title: Environmental Health Disparities and Environmental Justice:
dataset.description:
Often, the populations most vulnerable to the negative impacts of environmental hazards are low-income communities and/or communities of color. This compounding overlap is due to a host of systemic barriers that these communities face. This project aims to explore environmental health disparities in the United States by investigating the relationship between three variables of interest: (1) industrial lead waste released (explored via locations of landfills and lead released directly from factories), (2) high blood lead levels in children, and (3) household income.

Overlaying maps of these variables provided preliminary qualitative support for our hypotheses. For example, a close look at landfill locations compared to median home values revealed that landfills tended to be located around areas with higher home values, rather than within these districts. However, the scope of our analysis is limited by the data available, which was gathered at the county level.

dataset.title: Preserving African American Places: Growing Preservation's Potential as a Path for Equity
dataset.description: Preserving African American Places seeks to understand the implications of place-based injustice and their impact on the preservation of African American cultural heritage, as well as to identify preservation-based strategies for equitable growth and development that respect the historical and present-day realties and conditions of African American Neighborhoods.

dataset.title: Maps Show the Real Picture of Race and Equity in Oakland
dataset.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Geography provides a lens to examine and dismantle structural racism.
  • Displaying data and demographics on a map shows disparities in services and outcomes for different racial groups.
  • Input from residents and engagements across departments helps guide equitable city services.

dataset.title: Keeping track of Congress
dataset.description:
People for the People (P4TP) is a GIS community focused on educating and empowering community members to engage with civic issues. The group is creating geospatial solutions to re-center political issues back on the people—your friends, your family, your neighbors and you—and elevating marginalized communities. Leading up to the 2020 U.S. presidential election, P4TP will use GIS to re-imagine how we engage with politics and politicians by breaking down a complex system into digestible maps, apps, and stories that will live on after this year. Together, they'll weave a story of the people, at scales from local to national, across the political landscape of the United States.


Recent protests against police brutality and systemic racism across the country have stirred some politician's pens to draft legislation addressing these issues. You can use the web app below to explore what bills are on the table and who is pushing for change.

dataset.title: Exploring race relations in the United States
dataset.description:
People for the People (P4TP) is a GIS community focused on educating and empowering community members to engage with civic issues. The group is creating geospatial solutions to re-center political issues back on the people—your friends, your family, your neighbors and you—and elevating marginalized communities. Leading up to the 2020 U.S. presidential election, P4TP will use GIS to re-imagine how we engage with politics and politicians by breaking down a complex system into digestible maps, apps, and stories that will live on after this year. Together, they'll weave a story of the people, at scales from local to national, across the political landscape of the United States.

Recent racial events across the country (e.g. George Floyd, Ahmaud Arbery, Breonna Taylor and countless others) have caused many of us to shift our focus to better understand those in our community who are most impacted by disparities caused by the "race" factor. In just a few steps, using our app, you can explore community sentiments on racial relations in the U.S. by exploring key words submitted by community members.

dataset.title: Recap: Esri User Conference 2020
dataset.description: This blog post is a summary of Esri UC events and a call to action to our geospatial community to stay engaged and bring your talents to bear to address these issues.

dataset.title: Diversity, Equity, Inclusion & Racial Justice at the Esri User Conference 2020
dataset.description:
Esri and our users recognize that diversity, equity, inclusion, and racial justice are more important than ever. This year, during a national call for racial justice and a pandemic that has exposed long-standing societal inequities, we must come together as a geospatial community to address these issues. Because of this, we are bringing more content on these topics to the Esri UC than ever before.

To help you find your way to the sessions and events most relevant to diversity, equity, inclusion and racial justice, we have prepared this agenda to help you plan your UC experience. The events in this agenda center around 3 topics:

Equity & Social Justice

Diversity & Inclusion

Racial Justice

dataset.title: Create Inclusive Healthcare and Housing for LGBTQ+ Older Adults
dataset.description:
The City of Cambridge LGBTQ+ Commission is dedicated to helping create and promote welcoming agencies for people across all sexual orientations, gender identities and gender expressions. LGBTQ+ older adults in particular as they access housing and healthcare mainstream services are in need of places that allow them to be safe and affirmed in their identities, so they can age with dignity, respect, and receive proper care.

This Best Practices Guide is an informational tool that allows anyone: healthcare and housing professionals, older adults, caregivers, etc. to understand the needs of LGBTQ+ older adults, as well as how to support them in small, key ways that make a huge impact and difference.

Thank you for taking your time to learn about ways to support LGBTQ+ older adults and make your agency the most inclusive it can be!

dataset.title: Charleston Racial Equity Timeline
dataset.description:
First enslaved Africans arrive to South Carolina

South Carolina was a slave colony from its inception. Although the first Africans arrived in 1526 as part of a large Spanish expedition from the West Indies, planters who later emigrated from Barbados established large scale slavery in the Carolinas on indigo and rice plantations.

dataset.title: Augmenting Amache
dataset.description:
In this StoryMap from Eos Positioning Systems, we explore the stories of two men whose lives were connected by the Amache Internment Camp in southeastern Colorado. Using storytelling, #GIS, #GPS and #AR, they are making sure Japanese internment camps won't be lost to history.

In the first chapters, we meet Dennis Otsuji, a renowned landscape architect who was born at Amache in 1943. Then, we meet Jim Casey, a GIS user and philanthropist on a quest to preserve Amache. Casey uses Esri ArcGIS Online tools, Arrow Gold for ground control points, and augmented reality. In an unlikely twist, Otsuji and Casey meet one fateful day when Otsuji goes searching for his past, just as Casey is working to preserve the past.

Finally, the StoryMap ends with the first augmented-reality look at Amache.

dataset.title: Taking Pride

This interactive map documents the history of LGBT culture in and around Greenwich Village. Organized chronologically, it focuses on three important eras: The 19th Century, Early 20th Century, and sites associated with the LGBT Liberation Movement Since Stonewall. To learn more about these New York City landmarks, users may scroll through the illustrated text and click on the map’s highlighted sites.

dataset.title: Has Our City Achieved  A Fair Landscape？
dataset.description:
The resource equity behind the four Landscape Bridges in Chengdu, China is discussed through three aspects: landscape spatial equity, social equity and economic and cultural equity. It measures the convenience and proximity of citizens to landscape resources.

Explain in detail the walking accessibility of the bridge, the change of crowd activities in one day and the socio-economic situation within 1.5km around the bridge. Finally, it comes to the conclusion that the integrated development of landscape bridge and surrounding areas needs to grasp the cultural attribute in geographical space.

Key Words: Equity; Landscape bridges; Chengdu

dataset.title: MiEJScreen Web App Draft
dataset.description:
This interactive map application helps members of the public look at Environmental Justice concerns across Michigan. This web app consists of 26 environmental justice indicators within 4 major components. There is as also a over all EJ Score and 2 sub scores. All of these environmental justice layers are in percentiles. There are also numerus Context Layers.  See the MiEJScreen Technical Report and MiEJScreen Glossary for more details. 

MiEJScreen is a screening tool that provides percentile scoring of various environmental, health, and socioeconomic indicators to measure relative environmental risk factors in communities. The percentiles help compare various factors that may contribute to disparities within a community or between communities and should not be taken to be an absolute value. 

This map also does not model the overall burden on communities, nor does it reflect the actual number of individuals affected by environmental risk factors. This map also does not model the positive or negative likelihood of an individual health outcome. Therefore, it should not be used to diagnose a community health issue, to label a community or to attribute risk factors and exposures for specific individuals. Additional analysis is needed to make decisions on health outcomes that may be associated with the environmental risk factors. This map is intended to be a dynamic, informative tool. Decisions on the cumulative impact of environmental risk should not solely be based on this map.

For more information on Environmental Justice in Michigan, please visit https://www.michigan.gov/environmentaljustice/.

See MiEJScreen Technical Report for details on the component and the indicators.

For content related questions or to submit feedback please reach out to EGLE-Maps@Michigan.gov.


.

dataset.title: Census My Community Explorer
dataset.description:
In April, 2022, U.S. Census Bureau launched its latest data explorer tool, My Community Explorer (MCE). MCE is an interactive map-based tool that highlights demographic and socioeconomic data that measure inequality and can help inform data-based solutions. This tool is designed to h elp users identify underserved communities as directed by the President's Executive Order 13985 on Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Accessibility in the Federal Workforce. Data featured in this tool includes: Community Resilience Estimates (CRE), American Community Survey (ACS), County Business Patterns (CBP) and Nonemployer Statistics (NES). 

Please see About Data & How to Use for more information on the data and instruction for how to use the tool.
dataset.license: This tool is published and managed by U.S. Census Bureau. Please send feedback to ewd.outreach@census.gov

dataset.title: Chesapeake Bay Environmental Justice and Equity Dashboard
dataset.description:
The Chesapeake Bay Partnership Executive Council’s Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Justice (DEIJ) Statement commits to including DEIJ in all areas of Chesapeake Bay restoration and conservation.  A major element of addressing DEIJ is identifying the geography of issues and opportunities.

The Chesapeake Bay Program Principals’ Staff Committee issued a DEIJ Action Statement in 2020 that included five commitments.  Commitment three called for Advancement of the DEIJ Strategy through work plan development and implementation for all Chesapeake Bay Program Teams and Workgroups.  The Chesapeake Bay Environmental Justice and Equity Dashboard serves as one tool to help identify opportunities and challenges associated with this Strategy.

The Dashboard is a web application that integrates data from multiple sources to convey demographic, socioeconomic, environmental, and programmatic topics connected to the Chesapeake Bay Watershed Agreement and Chesapeake specific DEIJ initiatives.  It is currently accessible in this draft or beta release as we collect information from users on content and usability.  Please send comments or suggestions to diversitydashboard@chesapeakebay.net.

The Dashboard provides access to a variety of spatial data layers pertinent to addressing environmental issues in areas with underrepresented populations, which include communities of color, low income, and linguistically isolated communities. These data reflect demographic data of underrepresented populations, environmental justice and public health issues, quality of life concerns, and other data important for other Outcomes of the Chesapeake Bay Watershed Agreement of 2014.

The Dashboard is envisioned as a key tool for identifying conservation and restoration activities throughout the Bay Watershed where there may be one or more co-benefits combining environmental outcomes and diversity outcomes

dataset.title: North Carolina County Vulnerability to Natural Disaster
dataset.description:
This is a StoryMap developed for the 2020 ArcGIS Online Competition for US HS+MS Students. This StoryMap was created by a student who attends Athens Drive Magnet High School in Raleigh, North Carolina (Wake County).

Background

North Carolina has always been a prime target for hurricanes and tropical storms, as it sits on the east coast of the United States of America boarding the Atlantic Ocean. Just in the past decade, over 10 hurricanes and tropical storms have made landfall with the state. I've personally witnessed some of the tragedies that have come about a lack of natural disaster preparedness. As North Carolinian residents and emergency services prepare for this coming decade, it's important to determine which areas are most vulnerable and provide the necessary support to those regions.

StoryMap Development and Geographic Analysis

This StoryMap focuses on accessing North Carolinian counties' vulnerability to natural disasters, specifically hurricanes and tropical storms. The project analyzes different factors that signify natural disaster vulnerability including population density, various demographics, geography and flood exposure, Red Cross presence, and EMS and hospital availability and quality. Each of these factors' data layers were acquired from various sources listed below. These factors are then weighed into two sub-indexes, a Vulnerability Sub-Index and a Support/Preparation Sub-Index, based on whichever one the factor applies to. In order to properly organize and weigh each factor, my data was sort and calculated in multiple spreadsheets on Microsoft Excel before being imported into ArcGIS Online as a .csv file. These sub-indexes are then weighed into a single value for which each county is scored on. This final index score determines the overall vulnerability of the county. Mapping this index and sub-indexes, notable trends and patterns are found which don't only provide important insight into natural disaster vulnerability, but the current state of healthcare and services in these counties too.

Assistance and Special Thanks

A big thanks to Jeffery Hammerstein, Assistant Chief at WakeEMS, and all the amazing staff at Wake EMS for providing me with the entire North Carolina EMS Station Dataset, allowing me to compare my index scores with results and data from recent hurricanes, and inviting me to listen in on a Peer Review Session. I learned a lot about Wake County's role in North Carolina disaster relief and I cannot understate the impact our collaboration has had on this project! This project originally started as a much smaller project under the advisory of Dr. Eric Money with the NC State Center for Geospatial Analytics, but later expand into the individual project it is now. Lastly, thank you to Dr. Thomas Ray, my 4-H club leader, for providing me with StoryMap suggestions and revisions, allowing me to share my project with other 4-H groups, and teaching me everything I know about GIS today!

Works Cited/Data Layer Credits
  • WakeEMS: Peer Review Session Invitation, North Carolina EMS Station Dataset
  • ArcGIS Online/Living Atlas: Provided Hurricane Mapping, Poverty Ratio, Median Age, Education, Population Density, and Red Cross Chapter data layers
  • NOAA: Coastal Flood Exposure Data
  • Wikipedia: Background Information Regarding Hurricanes in North Carolina
  • PennState Depart of Geography and Climate: Research Study
  • Center for Medicare and Medicade Services: National Hospital Comparison Measure Dataset
Image Sources
  • Title Page Image
  • Index Weight Graphic (Made by Ameen)
  • Section I Landscape Image
  • North Carolina Hurricane Chart
  • Section II Landscape Image
  • WakeEMS Photographs (Taken by Ameen)
  • Section III Landscape Image
  • Ending Hurricane GIF (Moving Image)

dataset.title: PlacePoints
dataset.description:
PLACES (Population Level Analysis and Community Estimates) is an expansion of the original 500 Cities project and is a collaboration between the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation (RWJF), and the CDC Foundation (CDCF). The original 500 Cities Project provided city- and census tract-level estimates for the 500 largest US cities. PLACES extends these estimates to all counties, places (incorporated and census designated places), census tracts, and ZIP Code Tabulation Areas (ZCTA) across the United States. This service includes 29 measures for chronic disease related health outcomes (13), prevention measures (9), health risk behaviors (4), and health status (3). Data were provided by CDC Division of Population Health, Epidemiology and Surveillance Branch. Data sources used to generate these measures include BRFSS data (2019 or 2018), Census Bureau 2010 census population data or annual population estimates for county vintage 2019 or 2018, and American Community Survey (ACS) 2015-2019 or 2014-2018 estimates.

The health outcomes include arthritis, current asthma, high blood pressure, cancer (excluding skin cancer), high cholesterol, chronic kidney disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), coronary heart disease, diagnosed diabetes, depression, obesity, all teeth lost, and stroke.

The prevention measures include lack of health insurance, visits to doctor for routine checkup, visits to dentist, taking medicine for high blood pressure control, cholesterol screening, mammography use for women, cervical cancer screening for women, colon cancer screening, and core preventive services use for older adults (men and women).

The health risk behaviors include binge drinking, current smoking, physical inactivity, and sleeping less than 7 hours.

The health status measures include mental health not good for ≥14 days, physical health not good for ≥14 days, and fair or poor health. 

For more information, please visit https://www.cdc.gov/places or contact places@cdc.gov.

dataset.title: PBOT Equity Matrix
dataset.description:
PBOT's Equity Matrix

PBOT’s Equity Matrix assigns a score (maximum of 10) to every census tract using two of the three demographic variables: race and income. Both race and income are rated on an index from 1 to 5. For the race score, the higher the percentage of residents the U.S. Census Bureau defines as people of color or Latino in a census tract, the higher the score. For the income index, the lower the median household income, the higher the score.   

Data is much more inconsistent and unreliable for limited English proficiency (LEP). In the Equity Matrix, we have placed a bold edge around the census tracts where we find LEP higher than the citywide average of 3.8%. This helps tell part of the story and lets us see where these numbers overlap with our race and income scoring. 

Use the plus (+) and minus (-) buttons to zoom in and out. Use the magnifying glass search icon (🔍) to look up addresses or street names. Click on any census tract to see census data and scoring for that tract.   

For more information on how the Equity Matrix was developed and how the Matrix is used at PBOT, visit our What is the PBOT Equity Matrix? page. For technical assistance with the Equity Matrix, email pbotgissupport@portlandoregon.gov  

Data source for all demographic variables: 2014-2018 American Survey 5-year estimates

dataset.title: Vape & Tobacco Shop Proximity to Wake County High Schools
dataset.description:
Each tobacco and vape outlet near Wake County High Schools was evaluated using different layers in this story map. The tobacco and vape outlet list was developed by the Poe Center for Health Education. The buffer around Enloe High School was set as a 2.5-mile radius, and a count of tobacco shops was performed. An unreal 86 tobacco and vape outlets were discovered within this radius. These results prompted a further investigation of buffers around all high schools in Wake County. Using the Wake County Public Schools layer, schools were filtered to just high schools. 

The data showed a higher concentration of vape and tobacco outlets within the downtown Raleigh area and where many high schools are located, such as Enloe, Broughton, and Millbrook. Near these areas, there are more vape and tobacco outlets compared to other locations in Wake County. To further emphasize these findings, a hot spot layer was added, explicating the groupings of outlets. There are two explicit hot spots within the Enloe High School radius showing a high count of vape and tobacco outlets. To answer the question, are tobacco merchants targeting specific people, the Economic Health Index Series 2018  and the Vulnerability Assessment Index Series 2018 were added. In those same areas where there are high vape and tobacco outlets, it is also more vulnerable and less socioeconomically sound. 

There will be maps showing the tobacco and vape shop data in this story map, layers showing the concentrations, layers leading whom tobacco merchants target, examples of tobacco and vape shops near the Enloe High School community, and possible resolutions and solutions. 
The cluster analysis and second hotspot analysis were performed in ArcGIS Pro. All other analyses were performed in ArcGIS Online. 
Photos of tobacco outlets and Enloe High School were taken from Google Earth (street view).
dataset.license: This StoryMap has been developed for the 2021 ArcGIS Online Competition for US HS+MS Students. Information within this StoryMap may be used for educational purposes only.

dataset.title: Healthcare Access, Racial Equity and Maternal Mortality
dataset.description:
Healthcare access, racial equity and maternal mortality in New Orleans, Louisiana.

The layers in this map have been compiled into a single web map for use in this story map:
https://wkkf.maps.arcgis.com/home/item.html?id=0d10e82dad16415d8c34b6742b6dcce2

Hospitals
Hospitals in New Orleans are categorized according to availability of NICU facilities, and whether or not they have the Baby Friendly designation.

ACS Black Women Age 15-49
Data for this layer was filtered from ACS datasets within Community Analyst.

ACS Fertility in the Past 12 Months
ArcGIS original content reference layer
This layer shows fertility in past 12 months by age of mother. This is shown by tract centroid. This service is updated annually to contain the most currently released American Community Survey (ACS) 5-year data, and contains estimates and margins of error. There are also additional calculated attributes related to this topic, which can be mapped or used within analysis. The calculated percentages are slightly different from traditional age-specific fertility rates in that the total number of live births (due to twins or higher-order multiple births) is not available in this table. 

Federally Qualified Health Centers
Original reference data

dataset.title: Justice40 Atlas
dataset.description:
View this atlas of nine maps showing different categories of Justice40 disadvantaged tracts. App opens in Colorado, but has nation-wide coverage. Search for your area and browse through the maps. Data from Justice40 feature layer in Living Atlas. See this blog post for more information.

Items Included:
  • Justice40 by Number of Categories
  • Climate change
  • Clean energy and energy efficiency
  • Clean transit
  • Affordable and sustainable housing
  • Reduction and remediation of legacy pollution
  • Critical clean water and wastewater infrastructure
  • Health burdens
  • Training and workforce development

Purpose:

"Sec. 219.  Policy.  To secure an equitable economic future, the United States must ensure that environmental and economic justice are key considerations in how we govern.  That means investing and building a clean energy economy that creates well‑paying union jobs, turning disadvantaged communities — historically marginalized and overburdened — into healthy, thriving communities, and undertaking robust actions to mitigate climate change while preparing for the impacts of climate change across rural, urban, and Tribal areas.  Agencies shall make achieving environmental justice part of their missions by developing programs, policies, and activities to address the disproportionately high and adverse human health, environmental, climate-related and other cumulative impacts on disadvantaged communities, as well as the accompanying economic challenges of such impacts.  It is therefore the policy of my Administration to secure environmental justice and spur economic opportunity for disadvantaged communities that have been historically marginalized and overburdened by pollution and underinvestment in housing, transportation, water and wastewater infrastructure, and health care." Source: Executive Order on Tackling the Climate Crisis at Home and Abroad

dataset.title: Racial Equity in the City of Charleston, SC
dataset.description:
Racial equity is the condition where one’s race identity has no influence on how one fares in society. Race equity is one part of race justice and must be addressed at the root causes and not just the manifestations. This includes the elimination of policies, practices, attitudes, and cultural messages that reinforce differential outcomes by race.

﻿As an outcome, achieving racial equity would mean living in a world where race is no longer a factor in the distribution of opportunity. As a process, we apply racial equity when those most impacted by the structural racial inequities are meaningfully involved in the creation and implementation of the institutional policies and practices that impact their lives.

dataset.title: Solving Food Insecurity in a Los Angeles Community
dataset.description:
This "just sustainability" Story Map is a spatial analysis of food insecurity in a historically underserved community in Los Angeles. This digital map contextualizes four solutions to food insecurity in Pacoima—a historically underserved community within Los Angeles County—with layers on poverty, California food banks, and community demographics (e.g., race/ethnicity, age, and minority status).

Data on the boundaries of Pacoima by five-digit U.S. Postal ZIP code sourced from TomTom. Feature layer by Esri Data and Maps last updated April 2020.

Data for the choropleth map on poverty by census tracts comes from the U.S. Census Bureau American Community Survey (ACS) 2014-2018 5-Year Estimates. Feature layer by Esri Demographics Team last updated January 2020.

Data on USDA food banks in California comes from the California Department of Social Services and California Association of Food Banks, and was compiled by the California Governor's Office of Emergency Services (CalOES) GIS team. Feature layer by CalOES last updated January 2019.

Data on the solutions for food insecurity in Pacoima was collected with the Esri "Collector Classic" iOS app by Pacoima resident, Patricia Vargas, in April 2020 as part of a lab for "GEOG 201: Geospatial Science and Geographic Information" at Oregon State University (OSU) with Ms. Lorene Becker and Ph.D. candidate, Alexander Smith, during the Spring 2020 quarter. Feature layer by Patricia Vargas generated by running the "Derive New Locations" of GEOG201_400_S20 to filter and extract point data from user, vargasp, only; last updated May 2020.

Photography comes from Architizer; John McCoy; Justin Cram; Los Angeles District 7; Superior Grocers; and Thought Catalog on Unsplash. Last accessed May 2020.

Software Used: ArcGIS Enterprise, ArcGIS Online, Esri Classic Story Map, Esri Collector Classic for iOS 19.0.2, macOS Preview 11.0, and Microsoft Word for Mac 16.41

dataset.title: Freedom
dataset.description:
This story map draws upon the Library's rich audio-visual collections on the freedom struggle, principally located in the American Folklife Center, to illustrate the motivations and actions of a range of men and women who joined together under the banner of freedom, justice and equality for African Americans in the latter half of the twentieth century in the United States. In their own words, participants in the freedom struggle reflect on the hard, dangerous work they undertook to make the vision of a fair and just American society a reality. The presentation focuses on the "behind-the-scenes" stories of events like the murder of the teenager, Emmett Till (1955), the Albany Movement (1961), the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom (1963), the Selma to Montgomery Voting Rights March (1965), along with accounts of student activists in the Student Non-violent Coordinating Committee (SNCC). The presentation touches on several issues including the challenges of non-violent struggle, racial terror, relationships among and between various civil rights organizations, the leadership of grass-roots activists in the struggle, and other such topics.

The CSV files related to the data found in this Story Map are downloadable.

dataset.title: The Mapping of Race in America
dataset.description:
Mapping Race in America was created as part of the 2022 Junior Fellows Program at the Library of Congress and was inspired by the work of the Geography & Map Division in support of the U.S. House Select Committee on Economic Disparity and Fairness in Growth.

Using historical census maps, maps produced independently by other researchers, and information gleaned from historical newspapers, the project details the mapping of racial and economic inequality in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Further, this project connects the historical findings to modern issues pertaining to race and inequality, with case studies of Baltimore, New Orleans, and Tampa.

Picture it: You're out for a walk around your neighborhood. What do you see? What characteristics does it have? How would you describe it? How might someone else describe it?

Opinions and words matter in urban planning. Take a second to observe this example of the fictional city of Springfield.

dataset.title: Hospitalization and mortality data for heart disease and stroke
dataset.description:
Heart disease is the leading cause of death in the United States. This is true for both men and women, and for most racial and ethnic groups. About one in every four deaths can be attributed to heart disease. Heart disease also costs the United States hundreds of billions in health care services, medicines, and lost productivity (Source: CDC Heart Disease Facts).

Many organizations are trying to better understand where to intervene. Naturally, mapping is part of this work. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recently contributed the most recent county-level hospitalization and mortality rates for both heart disease and stroke from the CDC Interactive Atlas of Heart Disease and Stroke to ArcGIS Living Atlas, as well as high blood pressure medication nonadherence rates. High blood pressure is a key risk factor for heart disease.

dataset.title: Video: Racial and Identity Profiling Webinar May 2021
dataset.description:
In 2016, the California legislature passed Assembly Bill 953, the Racial and Identity Profiling Act (RIPA). RIPA mandates that California law enforcement agencies collect and report officer-perceived identity information including race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, and nationality of subjects of police stops. RIPA is meant to be used as a tool to monitor and ensure accountability and transparency among the 500+ police agencies in California. This data is then to be shared with the State of California Department of Justice and their RIPA Board where it will be used for the purpose of review, analysis, and research to eliminate racial and identity profiling in the State of California and improve police-community relations. The bill has been rolled out incrementally by agency size and every agency in the State is required to be reporting by April 1, 2023. 

 In this session, Sergeant Steve Rego from the City of Berkeley Police Department will present how BPD is using Survey123 to collect and share this data with the State as well as to support his agency’s own transparency and accountability efforts. Survey123 is an application that most city and county agencies already have access to through their current Esri licensing and the form-driven Survey123 is easily configurable to the RIPA questionnaire. Sergeant Rego will discuss how they set it up and rolled it out at their agency, how the app works, their review process, and how it gets shared to the DOJ to meet their reporting requirements. Sergeant Rego will be joined by John Beck and Jason Latoski from Esri to demonstrate the technology and share additional resources for your agency to get started.

dataset.title: Applying the Racial Equity Workflow Using ArcGIS
dataset.description:
About this Course

Many organizations are working toward a commitment to achieving racial equity within their communities. To achieve racial equity, it is important to have the capabilities to analyze inequities and provide change while engaging the community. ArcGIS can play a significant role in assisting organizations in applying the racial equity workflow to address inequities.

Goals
  • Apply a framework using ArcGIS to address racial inequities in an organization.
  • Use ArcGIS to expand community understanding of patterns of racial inequity.

Suggested Skills

Completion of ArcGIS Pro Basics and ArcGIS Online Basics or equivalent knowledge.

Software

To complete exercises, you need the following:

  • ArcGIS Pro 2.7 (Basic)
  • ArcGIS Online Organizational Account
    • Publisher role or equivalent
  • ArcGIS Dashboards

dataset.title: Analyze Racial Inequity During COVID-19
dataset.description: This inequity is a result of entrenched systemic inequality. Therefore, organizations must urgently respond with racially equitable crisis relief. To that end, a racially equitable response to COVID-19 means providing proportionately more resources to communities of color. To emphasize, these communities are unserved and underserved. Therefore, they lack the resources needed to withstand and recover from a crisis. Here, we will address how to analyze your community to understand where underserved populations reside.

dataset.title: Learn Lesson: Policy Mapping - Improve Newborn Health
dataset.description:
You want to suggest policy actions to your state government to improve newborn health and help reach this goal.

To do so, you'll create a policy map that identifies two groups of counties: those closest to meeting the goal and the major outliers impacting the state's average. You'll ensure your map visually communicates clear policy goals, and then share it as a web app.

This lesson is targeted toward government employees or any civic-minded individual who wants to make a difference in their community.

Requirements
  • Publisher or Administrator role in an ArcGIS organization (get a free trial) or ArcGIS Enterprise
View final result here

dataset.title: Learn Lesson: Map Breast Cancer Differences by Ethnicity
dataset.description:
Although the survival rate between those two ethnic groups is narrowing, significant disparities remain. In this lesson, you'll take a deep dive into those reasons by mapping mortality rates and risk factors.

Requirements
  • ArcGIS Pro Advanced (get a free trial)
  • Publisher or Administrator role in an ArcGIS organization
  • ArcGIS Spatial Analyst extension
View final result here

dataset.title: Racially Equitable COVID-19 Response Using GIS
dataset.description: Timely information about race and ethnicity is vital to assessing how COVID-19 and related measures are impacting vulnerable communities. A glance at the preliminary data from Michigan reveals stark inequities between racial groups. Similarly, in Wisconsin, the data shows that African Americans Have Contracted and Died of Coronavirus at an Alarming Rate. In Louisiana, where about 1/3 of the population is African American, 70% of people who have died from COVID-19 are black. Similar trends are appearing across the country.  These trends are due to historical inequities in distributional, process, and cross-generational equity. These inequities have not been addressed sufficiently in any arena for these communities.

dataset.title: Use ArcGIS Dashboards to Increase Racial Equity in Your COVID-19 Response
dataset.description:
Data from Michigan, Wisconsin, and Louisiana reveals that COVID-19 amplifies pre-existing racial inequities. As such, it is critical to manage your COVID-19 response to increase racial equity. Additionally, data about COVID-19 is rapidly changing. As more data becomes available and the crisis evolves, we need a dynamic response approach.
COVID-19 is shedding light on pre and existing racial disparities, and inequitable community conditions surrounding the novel coronavirus are evolving rapidly. For example, racial and economic inequalities are emerging in testing and treatment. Moreover, existing inequities in access to healthy food and healthcare are increasing the risk for communities of color. As such, there is an urgency to ensure racial equity in COVID-19 responses and response efforts are adapting accordingly.

dataset.title: New Data Collection Available: COVID-19 Health, Racial, and Economic Equity
dataset.description:
Health data shows the impact of the pervasive effects of racism in the United States. Health data is showing that…

  • Disproportionately Black U.S. communities carry the burden of more than half of both the country’s COVID-19 cases and deaths.
  • African Americans in New York City are dying at twice the rate of whites.
  • The death rate for Hispanic and Latino people falls in between, fifty percent higher than that of whites.
  • As of May 3rd, approximately 19% of the COVID-19 deaths in Arizona were among the Native American population even though they represent approximately 5.3% of the state’s population

dataset.title: Planning a Racially Equitable COVID-19 Recovery
dataset.description:
Black, Latinx, and Native American communities are disproportionately harmed by this crisis. As a result, recovery efforts must address the health and economic crisis with a racial equity lens. Focusing on racial equity during COVID-19 recovery means directing proportional resources toward where the needs are greatest in the community.  This helps to stop perpetuating existing inequalities.
GIS Can Support a Racially Equitable Recovery

GIS can help organizations make equitable policy and planning decisions. For example, GIS can help understand who will benefit most from any policy or plan. To exemplify, we will review GIS resources for equitable planning. We will focus on three scenarios:

  • Support Women- and/or Minority-Owned Businesses
  • Plan Coronavirus Testing Site Locations Equitably
  • Evaluate County Readiness for Relaxing Stay-at-Home Measures Equitably

dataset.title: Maps Inform Public Policy, Help Turn Plans into Actions
dataset.description:
Data for decision making has long been the purpose and design of a geographic information system (GIS). In fact, ‘Data for Decision’ is the title of a documentary video created in 1967 that highlights the pioneering work of Roger Tomlinson, the father of GIS.

Much has changed since the early days of government-funded systems designed to guide only the very large public policy discussions. GIS tools and data are fundamentally more accessible and intuitive, a development that has expanded the use of GIS beyond the specialist.

Key Takeaways

  • Governments at all scales use GIS to plan, measure and improve operations, and guide policy.
  • Location-based applications gather data quickly to inform a live system of actionable information.
  • Esri Maps for Public Policy packages maps, data, case studies, analysis examples, and lessons in themed bundles that address common challenges.

dataset.title: Helping Los Angeles Tackle the Need for Park Equity
dataset.description: Although it’s been more than 50 years since the Watts riots near Los Angeles took place, the aftermath of the unrest can still be seen today. Many of the businesses torched by rioters never returned. Lack of investments in the community has had a significant impact on the quality of life and the health of Watts residents.

dataset.title: LGBTQ History in Austin
dataset.description:
Oakwood Cemetery Chapel presents “To Liberate,” a digital exhibit about the Watson Chateau and its owners.

The Oakwood Chapel Winter 2022 exhibit "To Liberate" reveals the cultural history of the Watson Chateau, believed to have been built in 1853 by Margaret Neville Bowie, Rezin Bowie’s widow, and sister-in-law to Jim Bowie. Enslaved people also lived on the property. Subsequent owners included doctors, land speculators, attorneys, farmers, a hairstylist, a secretary, and lastly, a gay couple. They lived together at The Chateau for almost 50 years, hosting fabulous, well-known parties for the elite of Austin, Texas--and more quietly for the city’s closeted gay men. The house still stands but is rapidly deteriorating. A long unanswered question remains about the fate of the Watson Chateau. How will the current owner, The University of Texas at Austin, treat the property as the Dell Medical campus expands? Many Austinites hope that it will be saved and its history will be liberated for future generations.

Oakwood Cemetery was situated just northeast of the city limits. Now, after decades of city expansion, the cemetery is in the heart of Austin. The cemetery holds the namesakes of many Austin buildings, streets, and beloved parks. The final resting place for more than 23,000 people, Oakwood Cemetery remains an enduring link to the community, cultures, and life stories that built the great city just beyond its gates.

 

The Oakwood Cemetery Chapel was created in 1914, 75 years after the cemetery was founded, to host funeral and memorial services on site. The cemetery is evidence of the changing city and the past century’s shifting attitudes about mortuary services. Reopened in spring 2019, the Chapel is part of the Museums and Cultural Programs Division of the Parks and Recreation Department of the City of Austin. The Chapel is a visitor center where we can, as an act of remembrance, learn about our cultural heritage through the people who were buried in the surrounding cemetery. Genealogy reveals our forebearers' influence on the past and future. We share and collect individual narratives to create a framework for the collective human story.

 

Oakwood Cemetery Chapel's digital history exhibits are published here:

www.austintexas.gov/page/oakwood-cemetery-chapel-resources

dataset.title: CDC OMH Texas Social Vulnerability Index 2018
dataset.description:
The Minority Health Social Vulnerability Index (MH SVI) is an extension of CDC/ATSDR Social Vulnerability Index, which uses demographic variables to help local officials identify communities that may need support before, during, or after disasters. In addition to the standard CDC/ATSDR SVI themes of Socioeconomic Status, Household Composition & Disability, Minority Status & Language, and Housing & Transportation, the MH SVI includes statistics on race, ethnicity, and language groups, as well as themes for Health Care Access & Infrastructure and Medical Vulnerability. Developed in collaboration with HHS Office of Minority Health.


This dataset includes individual variables, theme percentile rankings, and overall percentile rankings for 3,142 counties or equivalent areas in the United States. An interactive dashboard with full documentation is available via the Minority Health Social Vulnerability Index Explorer.

Data Sources
  • American Community Survey 2014-2018 5-Year Estimates, US Census Bureau
  • Homeland Infrastructure Foundation Level Data Open, US Department of Homeland Security
  • Health Resources and Services Administration
  • Interactive Atlas of Heart Disease and Stroke, US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
  • Diabetes Surveillance System, US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
  • Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation
For more information about this dataset, please contact the CDC/ATSDR SVI Coordinator.

It does not represent an official survey and represents only the approximate relative location of features and boundaries. Mapping may not necessarily reflect on-the-ground conditions. dataset.title: Redlining in the Twin Cities in 1934: 1960's and Today
dataset.description: This series of maps provides a window into the racial and demographic makeup of the Twin Cities in 1940, 1970, and today. It shows how the racial patterns identified and solidified by the Home Owners’ Loan Corporation (HOLC) map persist through to the present, and how the redlining of the 1930s reflects inequality in the Twin Cities today in terms of transportation, affordable housing and mortgage lending. The series also include information and stories about specific historic places, incidents and local activists that have shaped and championed civil rights and fair housing, both locally and nationally. Finally, it includes links to news stories and reports that give greater context to civil rights issues.

dataset.title: Celebrating Black Environmentalists
dataset.description:
In the face of racism and white supremacy — two forces that have long excluded Black, brown, and Indigenous people in environmental policy, conservation, and public health issues—the individuals profiled below have ushered in tremendous change. They’ve influenced environmental policy while simultaneously educating others on the structural racism that exists in the environmental movement even now.

These activists have paved the way for a more inclusive environmental movement by working on structural and deep rooted issues faced today. Let's celebrate their work.

"People of color have long been excluded from environmental policy and conservation ... [which perpetuates] inequality." — National Geographic

dataset.title: CalEnviroScreen 4.0 and Race/Ethnicity Analysis
dataset.description: CalEnviroScreen scores represent a combined measure of pollution and the potential vulnerability of a population to the effects of pollution. Like the previous versions, CalEnviroScreen 4.0 does not include indicators of race/ethnicity or age. However, the distribution of the CalEnviroScreen 4.0 cumulative impact scores by race or ethnicity is important. This information can be used to better understand issues related to environmental justice and racial equity in California. CalEPAs racial equity team has released a StoryMap using CalEnviroScreen 3.0 data that examines the connection between racist land use practices of the 1930s and the persistence of environmental injustice. The CalEPA StoryMap, along with this analysis, are examples of information that can be used to better understand issues related to environmental justice and racial equity in California.

dataset.title: Learn Lesson:Examine racial inequities in unsolved murder cases
dataset.description:
In this lesson, you'll use statistical analysis in ArcGIS Pro to identify American cities where unsolved homicides are most prevalent. Then, you'll assess which segments of the population are most impacted and determine whether there is any racial or demographic inequity in regards to unsolved homicides. This workflow doesn't address why homicides remain unsolved; the reasons are complex and varied. But as you work through the lesson, you'll have opportunities to think about possible causes and implications.

This lesson is for GIS analysts interested in learning about strategies for analyzing social and racial equity. You'll develop skills in summarizing and mapping central tendency, analyzing categorical data, and creating regions from points.

<h4 class="leader-1 trailer-half" style="font-weight: 400; margin: 1.5rem 0px 0.75rem; font-size: 1.414rem; line-height: 1.5;">Requirements</h4>
  • ArcGIS Pro (get a free trial)

dataset.title: Make a Map About Your Community
dataset.description:
A large subset of data from the American Community Survey(ACS) was recently added to the ArcGIS Living Atlas of the World. This data, sourced by the U.S. Census Bureau, covers topics such as housing, income, education, healthcare, and more. These ready-to-use ACS layers are updated annually to contain the most current 5-year estimates. This means that if you make a map using these layers, your map will always have the most current data!

Creating a useful map on a subject important to your community can be done in 4 easy steps.

dataset.title: Health, Racial & Economic Equity Data Group
dataset.description:
This gallery contains a collection of Esri maps, data, and apps that can help guide decisions around health, racial, and economic equity. It includes layers that can support analyses related to the social determinants of health (economic stability, neighborhood and physical environment, education, food, community and social context, and health care system). 

Includes data on race, ethnicity, age, gender, immigration, language, child well-being, senior well-being, disability status, health insurance, income, disposable income, home ownership, housing costs, air quality, homelessness, diversity, food access, savings vulnerability, education, internet access, family living arrangements, population, poverty, transportation, unemployment, social vulnerability, occupations, business & economic vulnerability, life expectancy, low birth weight, COVID-19 providers, social distancing, and more.

dataset.title: New Orleans Community Action Hub
dataset.description: Create your own initiative by combining existing applications with a custom site. Use this initiative to form teams around a problem and invite your community to participate.
dataset.license: null

dataset.title: Researchers Map Prejudice in Minneapolis’ Past
dataset.description:
Restrictive racial language in property deeds was a common practice throughout the US. It ties to English land law and the ruling that a restrictive covenant can ‘run with the land,’ making all future owners subject to restrictions that prior owners conceived. In Minneapolis, developers typically placed these covenants. They used the fears and prejudices of the time as a marketing tool to sell new developments. This practice is referred to as redlining, and the institutional practice has been found in hundreds of US cities where a federal agency, the Home Owner’s Loan Corporation created residential security maps and banks and real estate firms perpetuated the practice for decades.

Key takeaways

  • Racial segregation was shaped via a history of enforceable property covenants.
  • Past property practices still impact individuals and the makeup of cities today.
  • Mapping change quickly conveys patterns of history that can be explored for implications.

dataset.title: Civil Rights, Inclusion & Opportunity Annual Report
dataset.description:
An interactive overview of the work the City of Detroit's Civil Rights, Inclusion and Opportunity Department (CRIO) performed over the course of Fiscal Year 2019. Included are CRIO team descriptions, metrics and maps concerning the various responsibilities with which CRIO is tasked and plans for the coming year. 

For more information, please visit the CRIO website and follow CRIO on Facebook.

dataset.title: Clearing the Air in the Historic West End
dataset.description:
Historic West End residents lacked the data needed to show that they were breathing disproportionately high levels of air pollution. Air pollution can vary by as much as eight times within the span of a single city block. The air quality data produced by the nearest monitoring station didn’t reflect what Historic West End residents were actually breathing.

Over the course of 3 years, leaders in the Historic West End worked with Clean Air Carolina to research historic environmental justice issues, and develop a community lead vision for a brighter future.

dataset.title: Maps and Data Strengthen Calls for Housing Equity in Houston
dataset.description:
Texas Housers examines racial equity to deliver equitable housing in Houston.

Key Takeaways

  • Study illustrates how residents of Houston, Texas, are divided along racial lines.
  • Maps illuminate the differences in quality of life between White and Black low-income residents.
  • Data visualization lends context to residents’ lived experiences, supports struggle for equitable housing.

dataset.title: Hiring for Equity and Inclusion during a Pandemic
dataset.description: Successful digital transformation often serves as a foundation for location intelligence, empowering companies to map and analyze data that fuels new insight. With everything from cleaning regulations to supply chains in flux due to COVID-19 uncertainty, digital dashboards provide executives the hyper-local awareness needed to make smart business decisions in each market, each day.

dataset.title: Can a Map Speak for Those Who Cannot Speak for Themselves?
dataset.description:
The problems we hear on the news—homelessness, income inequality, unemployment, opioid abuse, blight, community policing, access to public transit, food deserts—all point to the social issues we should be applying data and analysis to solve.
Does your organization feel the pressure to address these social inequities? Is this an opportunity for GIS professionals to become superheroes in social justice?
Governments have been producing demographic maps that show basic population information for decades. However, Stephen Goldsmith, director of the Innovations in American Government Program at Harvard’s Kennedy School of Government, has observed that we need to shift from demographic maps to policy maps that showcase the opportunity to intervene and overcome social inequalities today.

dataset.title: Location Technology Helps the Legally Vulnerable After Disasters
dataset.description:
Lawyers are among the wave of second responders when disasters happen, and many take up the needs of the legally vulnerable. The Florida Bar Foundation aggregates data about marginalized communities likely to be overlooked in recovery efforts. Then it uses location-based insights to raise awareness and raise funds, building the case about the effectiveness of legal services to help lobbyists seeking greater federal assistance.

Key takeaways

  • GIS helps quantify the needs of the most-vulnerable populations.
  • Location data presents relatable details to help guide those that help the legally vulnerable.
  • Looking at needs geographically provides a scientific approach to prioritize limited funds.

dataset.title: Community Engagement for Racial Equity During COVID-19
dataset.description: Communities of color have historically been unserved and underserved with needed resources for thriving. This means they have suffered more during times of crisis. COVID-19 is no different. Underserving and not serving communities of color predictably puts them at a great disadvantage for risk and death during a pandemic. Therefore, proactive engagement is critical. This pandemic is disproportionately burdening people of color. Given this truth, our response to COVID-19 must be consciously equitable. Prioritize meaningful, participatory engagement with communities of color for an equitable COVID-19 response.

dataset.title: Presenting breakdowns by race/ethnicity (or any groups) in your maps
dataset.description: If you’re working with health or economic data, you probably want to address the differences by occupation, age group, sex, race/ethnicity, veteran status, or educational attainment. Instead of making a separate map for each and every group, you can present the breakdowns in one map. This minimizes work for you, and also helps your audience more able to digest the information since they won’t be overwhelmed by multiple maps. There are few different techniques for incorporating and presenting breakdowns by different groups in your maps: configuring the pop-up to show a simple chart or short list, using a whole range of different mapping styles, and even labeling the map in certain ways. The result will be fewer but more informative maps that can help identify opportunities to address inequalities.

dataset.title: Make a Map About Your Community in 4 Easy Steps
dataset.description:
Creating a useful map on a subject important to your community can be done in 4 easy steps:

1 – Find a topic of interest

2 – Filter to your area

3 – Map a new variable

4 – Finalize and save

dataset.title: Indicators of Poverty and Urban Stress by Ward
dataset.description:
Use this tool to view maps and comparative statistics of the main indicators from the Poverty and Urban Stress Report: poverty, income, crime, race and education. See how the data vary across wards in Tucson and zoom in on areas of interest to you.

This Story Map compiles multiple map-based dashboards to show statistics on income, poverty, education, and race by ward across Tucson. Users can use the ward filters at the top of each dashboard to view just the ward they are interested in, or compare one ward to another.  Each map is interactive: when individual census tracts are selected, users get details about that tract and how it compares to the rest of the ward or county.  

Data for the maps and graphs are from American Community Survey, which has been apportioned by ward using ESRI's summarize within tool.

dataset.title: Juneteenth in McKinney, Texas
dataset.description: The story of Juneteenth is the story of a holiday that is both uniquely African-American and uniquely Texan. Emancipation was celebrated in many ways and on many dates throughout the post-Civil War US, but Juneteenth is rooted in the specific experience of Black Texans. Beginning in Galveston on June 19, 1865, the Union Army's official order of Emancipation quickly transformed into a Black Texan holiday which spread rapidly throughout the state. By 1875, the Bonham Christian Messenger of Fannin County in far north-central Texas was reporting June 19th celebrations by "colored people everywhere."

dataset.title: To Liberate
dataset.description:
Oakwood Cemetery Chapel presents “To Liberate,” a digital exhibit about the Watson Chateau and its owners.

The Oakwood Chapel Winter 2022 exhibit "To Liberate" reveals the cultural history of the Watson Chateau, believed to have been built in 1853 by Margaret Neville Bowie, Rezin Bowie’s widow, and sister-in-law to Jim Bowie. Enslaved people also lived on the property. Subsequent owners included doctors, land speculators, attorneys, farmers, a hairstylist, a secretary, and lastly, a gay couple. They lived together at The Chateau for almost 50 years, hosting fabulous, well-known parties for the elite of Austin, Texas--and more quietly for the city’s closeted gay men. The house still stands but is rapidly deteriorating. A long unanswered question remains about the fate of the Watson Chateau. How will the current owner, The University of Texas at Austin, treat the property as the Dell Medical campus expands? Many Austinites hope that it will be saved and its history will be liberated for future generations.

Oakwood Cemetery was situated just northeast of the city limits. Now, after decades of city expansion, the cemetery is in the heart of Austin. The cemetery holds the namesakes of many Austin buildings, streets, and beloved parks. The final resting place for more than 23,000 people, Oakwood Cemetery remains an enduring link to the community, cultures, and life stories that built the great city just beyond its gates.

 

The Oakwood Cemetery Chapel was created in 1914, 75 years after the cemetery was founded, to host funeral and memorial services on site. The cemetery is evidence of the changing city and the past century’s shifting attitudes about mortuary services. Reopened in spring 2019, the Chapel is part of the Museums and Cultural Programs Division of the Parks and Recreation Department of the City of Austin. The Chapel is a visitor center where we can, as an act of remembrance, learn about our cultural heritage through the people who were buried in the surrounding cemetery. Genealogy reveals our forebearers' influence on the past and future. We share and collect individual narratives to create a framework for the collective human story.

 

Oakwood Cemetery Chapel's digital history exhibits are published here:

www.austintexas.gov/page/oakwood-cemetery-chapel-resources

dataset.title: Mapping the Destruction of Tennessee's African American Neighborhoods
dataset.description: A visual exploration of the effect of mid-20th century public works projects on African American neighborhoods in Chattanooga, Knoxville, Memphis, and Nashville.
dataset.license: If the application is shared or used, please credit the Tennessee State Library and Archives

dataset.title: Racial and Social Equity Index Viewer
dataset.description:
Click a census tract on the map to view the details.  Click "Legend" above to explore other demographic layers.

The Racial and Social Equity Index combines information on race, ethnicity, and related demographics with data on socioeconomic and health disadvantages to identify where priority populations make up relatively large proportions of neighborhood residents. 

The Composite Index includes sub-indices of:   

Race, English Language Learners, and Origins Index 
ranks census tracts by an index of three measures weighted as follows:

   Persons of color (weight: 1.0)
 English language learner (weight: 0.5)
  Foreign born (weight: 0.5)

Socioeconomic Disadvantage Index 
ranks census tracts by an index of two equally weighted measures:

 Income below 200% of poverty level 
 Educational attainment less than a bachelor’s degree

Health Disadvantage Index 
ranks census tracts by an index of seven equally weighted measures:

 No leisure-time physical activity
  Diagnosed diabetes 
   Obesity
 Mental health not good 
  Asthma
Low life expectancy at birth
 Disability

The index does not reflect population densities, nor does it show variation within census tracts which can be important considerations at a local level.

Produced by City of Seattle Office of Planning & Community Development. 

For more information on the indices, including guidance for use, contact 
Diana Canzoneri (diana.canzoneri@seattle.gov).

Get the data for this map from SeattleGeoData

Sources: 2011-2015 Five-Year American Community Survey
Estimates, U.S. Census Bureau; estimates from the 
Centers for Disease Control’ Behavioral Risk Factor 
Surveillance System (BRFSS) published in the 
“The 500 Cities Project,” 
Washington State Department of Health’s Washington 
Tracking Network (WTN), and estimates form the 
Public Health – Seattle & King County (based on the 
Community Health Assessment Tool).
Language is for population age 5 and older.  
Educational attainment is for the population age 25 and over.
Life expectancy is life expectancy at birth. 
Other health measures based on percentages of the adult population.

dataset.title: Dayton Transparency Portal
dataset.description:
Welcome to the City of Dayton’s Police Transparency Portal. As Policing in the 21st century continues to evolve, the City of Dayton recognizes the importance of increased communication, transparency, and accountability. The Dayton Transparency Portal is designed to provide a “one-stop” web page to access public information related to the Dayton Police Department’s data, policies, and resources.

On June 18, 2020, the Dayton City Commission announced a working structure that will be used to drive changes in policing. The working groups will address each of five reform areas. The City expects most of this process will occur over six to nine months, but some policy changes may be enacted sooner. Based on recommendations of the five working groups, this page will evolve. We invite you to contact us with suggestions on what information you would like to see included within this portal.

For more information on the five working groups, please visit Police Reform page.

dataset.title: Proportional seats held by Women in National Parliament
dataset.description:
This layer displays the proportion of national parliament seats held by women at the country level in 2019.

According to the World Bank:"Despite much progress in recent decades, gender inequalities remain pervasive in many dimensions of life - worldwide. But while disparities exist throughout the world, they are most prevalent in developing countries. Gender inequalities in the allocation of such resources as education, health care, nutrition, and political voice matter because of the strong association with well-being, productivity, and economic growth. These patterns of inequality begin at an early age, with boys routinely receiving a larger share of education and health spending than do girls, for example. Women are vastly underrepresented in decision-making positions in government, although there is some evidence of recent improvement. Gender parity in parliamentary representation is still far from being realized. Without representation at this level, it is difficult for women to influence policy. A strong and vibrant democracy is possible only when parliament is fully inclusive of the population it represents. Parliaments cannot consider themselves inclusive, however, until they can boast the full participation of women. This is not just about women's right to equality and their contribution to the conduct of public affairs, but also about using women's resources and potential to determine political and development priorities that benefit societies and the global community."
Source: The World Bank
